subSubSection.paragraph:
Cleistopetalum sumatranum
can also be synonymised to an already described species. It is readily identifiable as
Polyalthia clavigera King (1892: 60)
, a cauliflorous species rather similar to
P. sinclairiana .
Sinclair (1955) outlines the difference between the two species.
Polyalthia clavigera
is known from the Malay Peninsula, Sumatra and Borneo. However there is a twist in the tale. Beccari (1871: 188) described
Polyalthia anomala
from Sarawak in Borneo and I suspect that no specimen other than the type has been identified as belonging to this species. The mystery surrounding the species stems largely from the absence of duplicates of the type in major herbaria with the holotype in Florence. The staff of the Florence Herbarium kindly provided photographs of the type. I have come to the conclusion that Beccari’s species is the same as
Polyalthia clavigera
. Beccari’s type consists of a leafy twig and some small flowers in a packet that were illustrated in the original publication. Beccari described the large golden fruits to 10 cm long, but did not make a specimen of them.
Polyalthia clavigera
is easily recognised by its large club-shaped monocarps that dry black and wrinkled. It is less often collected in flower than fruit. The flowers of the Beccari type are a good match for immature flowers of
P. clavigera
particularly so to the type of
P. glomerata King (1892: 61)
, a synonym of
P. clavigera
.
Polyalthia clavigera
has been recorded from Gunung Matang in Sarawak (e.g.
S 12638
,
S 20893
, details below), the type locality of
P. anomala
. As
P. anomala
was published more than 20 years before
P. clavigera
it has priority over the latter and Beccari’s name must be used for the species.
